\( X_{a} = X_{a}^{dagger} \) Linearly independent They form a basis in a linear vector space The form an algera under comuutation called a Lie algebra Lie Algrebra $$ [X_{a}, X_{b}] = if_{abc}X_{c} $$ where \( [A, B] = AB - BA \)

content:
Ising model is an approximation model that captures the evolution of states influenced by their neighbor states and an external agent. It was first introduced to tackle the problem of phase transition of ferromagnetism but later adopted into other fields of science. In this review of Ising model, I will show the steps of solving the one dimensional Ising Model by transfer matrix method.
Introduction For subatomic system, all interactions have to be quantum mechanical. So in deriving the Hamiltonian of the Ising Model, we need to take the coupling of the orbital and spin angular momentum into account to derive the Hamiltonian in the system.
In the case of ferromagnetic materials, it turn out that from theoretical and experimental investigations have so far shown that, for all ferromagnetic materials, data on the temperatuer depenednece of M fit best with the values of total angular momentum of \( J = 1/2 \) and gyroscopic ratio of \( g = 2.0023\approx 2 \) in this model. So, we could consider only the spin degree of freedom matters. It is also reasonable that the spin interaction is short range, meaning only the nearest neighboring atoms matters to the evolution of the states of a chosen atom.
Writing out the Hamiltonian for arbitrary dimension we get
$$ H = -2J \sum_{i>j}\sigma_{i} \sigma_{j} - \mu B \sum_{i} \sigma_{i} $$
Where the \( \sigma \) representing the spin of atom \( i,j \), and it could be positive 1 or negative 1 to denote the top spin and down spin. The first summation include all the nearest neighbor interaction where J is the interaction constant. While the second summation shows the total interaction from a external magnetic field of \(B\) with a magnetic constant of \( \mu \).
The transfer matrix method aims to solve for the thermodynamic properties of the system by calculating the partition function from the Hamiltonian. Subsequently, the free energy of the system as well as its physical properties could be calculated in terms of system’s parameters such as temperature or the interaction energy.
Transfer matrix method Writting the Hamiltonian operator in energy and re-define the constant for simplification we get the following expression
$$ E(\sigma) = -J \sum_{j}^{N} \sigma_{j} \sigma_{j+1} - H \sum_{j}^{N} \sigma_{j} $$
With the partition function defined to be \( Z = e^{\beta E} \) , where \( beta = k_{b}T \) and \( k_{b} \) is the Boltzemann constant and \(T\) the temperature of the system. The partition function for the one dimension Ising Model is then written as
$$ Z_{N} = \sum_{\sigma} exp \left[ k\sum_{j}^{N} \sigma_{j} \sigma_{j+1} + h \sum_{j}^{N} \sigma_{j} \right] $$
By some arithmatic derivation which we will not be going through here, the N partition function \( Z_{N} \) could be written as the trace of a N matrix product \( T^{N} \), \( Z_{N} = tr(T^{N}) \) where T is defined to be the transfer matrix and is given by
$$ V = [[e^{k+h}, e^{-k}], [e^{-k}, e^{k-h}]] $$
It turns out that the transfer matrix is symmetric hence could be diagonlized into matrix with entries of its eigenvalues. As shown in the follwing equations
$$ T = PDP^{-1} = P[[\lambda_{1}, 0], [0, \lambda_{2}]]P^{-1} $$
Carrying out N multiplication,
$$ T^{N} = PDP^{-1}PDP^{-1} … PDP^{-1}= PD^{N}P^{-1} $$
Using the property of trace that the trace of a matrix would be invariant under similarity transformation, the partition function is further simplify to summation of the eigenvalues of the transfer matrix
$$ Z_{N} = tr(PD^{N}P^{-1}) = tr(D^{N}) = \lambda_{+}^{N} + \lambda_{-}^{N} $$
In the language of thermodynamic, the partition function has the physical significant of statistical portion of a system. With all the states equally probable then the partion function of N particles captures all the macroscopic properties such as the free energy which is defined to be \( F = \ln{Z_{N}} \).
Introducing the quantity free energy per lattice site \( f = F/N \), we will be looking at a expression that is independet to the size of the system.
$$ \beta N^{-1}F = \ln(\lambda_{1}) + N^{-1} \ln \left[ 1+ \left( \frac{\lambda_{2}}{\lambda_{1}} \right)^{N} \right]$$
Assuming \( \lambda_{1} > \lambda_{2} \), and in the thermodynamic limit we expect \( N \rightarrow \infty \) then the last term vanish and giving us the free energy per lattice site as
$$ f = -k_{B}T \ln(\lambda_{1}) $$
Solving \( \lambda \) from the transfer matrix, which yields
$$ \lambda_{\pm} = e^{k}\cosh{h} \pm (e^{2k}\sinh^{2}h + e^{-2k})^{1/2} $$
Subsequently the free energy per site could be written as
$$ f(h, T) = -k_{B}T [e^{k} \cosh{h} + (e^{2k}\sinh^{2}h + e^{-2k})^{1/2}]$$
And the magnetization which is defined to be \( \frac{\delta f(h, T)}{\delta h}\) could be written as
$$ \frac{\delta f(h, T)}{\delta h} = M(h, T) = \frac{e^{k}\sinh{\beta H}}{(e^{2k}\sinh^{2}\beta H + e^{-2k})^{1/2}}$$
We visualize the dependence of magnetization on the external field with three different temperature values.
As shown in the above figure, in the lowest temperature where \(\beta = 1.5 \), the spin align perfectly to the external field. As the temperature goes up, the spin orientation becomes less susceptible to the external field.
Noting that \( M(H, T) \) being an analytic function for real \( H \) and non-zero positive \( T \). Meaning the physical and observable quantity in the system undergoes smooth transition with varing external magnetic field or change of temperature. Hence, there will be no phase transitions for the one dimensional Ising model.
Final Remarks As claimed ealier in this blog, there is no phase transition in the one dimensional Ising Model. In fact, Ising, being first one to solve the model further concluded that there will be no phase transition in arbitrary dimension. Seein the extensive application of Ising Model in various field of science we clearly know that it is not true. But back in the days of Ising, when a physicist put his full effort into some mathematical model but ended up with the conclusion that the model being non-physical…

Quantum Mechanics is formulated by serveral axioms. But different from other branches of physics, ones could hardly relate the axioms of quantum mechanics(QM) to their daily experience which makes QM such a weird and fascinating subject to study.
Though not having a relatable daily experience, those axioms reflect some profound structure of the nature if we turn our scope to the information theory and group theory. For example, a unitary evolvution is required transformation of the quantum states is closely related to the special unitary group in group theory. Bearing this motivation in mind, this note serves to state the seven axioms of quantum mechanics introduced in the book “Experimental Approach of Quantum Mechanics” by, and then explore its intuition in branches of mathematical physics.
Stating the Postulates Rule 1: A dynamical system corresponds to a Hilbert space in such a way that a definite state of the ssytem corresponds to a definite ray in the space. a state \(\left| u \right\rangle \)if it corresponds to the ray in the direction of vector \(\left| u \right\rangle\) complex factor and phase factor don’t change its state linear combination of definite state produces another possible state linear superposition principle relative phase between states matters An isolated quantum mechanical system can evolve with time unitarily. The evolution is continuous and causal.
let \( t>t_{0} \), then
$$ \left| u(t) \right\rangle = U(t, t_{0})\left| u(t_{0}) \right\rangle$$
For small \( t-t_{0} \Rightarrow U\) must differ only infinitesimally from the identity if it’s continous
$$ U(t_{0} + \delta t, t_{0}) = I - i K \delta t $$
where K is Hermitian.
By dimensional analysis, \( U(t_{0} + \delta t), t_{0} =I - \frac{i}{\hbar}H\delta t \)
$$ \left|u(t_{0} + \delta t) \right\rangle = \left( I - \frac{i}{\hbar}H\delta t \right) $$
Time dependent Schroedinger equation $$ H \left| u(t) \right\rangle = i\hbar \frac{\delta \left| u(t) \right\rangle }{\delta t} $$
$$ i\hbar \delta_{t} \left[ U(t, t_{0})\left|u(t_{0}) \right\rangle \right] = HU(t, t_{0}) \left| u(t_{0}) \right\rangle$$
Hamiltonians at different times commute
$$ \frac{\delta}{\delta t} U(t, t_{0}) = -\frac{i}{\hbar} H U(t, t_{0}) $$
Providing that H does not depend on time $$ U(t, t_{0}) = e^{\left[-\frac{i}{\hbar}\int_{t_{0}}^{t}H(t^{\prime})dt^{\prime}\right]} $$
if H does not commute at differen time, expansion about identity
$$ e^{\left[-\frac{i}{\hbar}\int_{t_{0}}^{t}H(t^{\prime})dt^{\prime}\right]_{t}} $$
Rule 2: An isolated quantum state evolves continously and casually in time by a unitary operator U. $$ \left| u(t) \right\rangle = U(t, t_{0}) \left | u(t_{0}) \right\rangle $$
where \( U(t, t_{0}) = e^{\left[-\frac{i}{\hbar}\int_{t_{0}}^{t}H(t^{\prime})dt^{\prime}\right]}\)
Rule 3: Each observable of a system is associated with a Hermitian operator on the Hilbert space of the system. We assume that the eigenstates of each observable form a complete set. Rule 4: The result of any given measurement of an observabble is an eigenvalue of yhe corresponding Hermitian operator. Rule 5: The average \( \bar{A} \equiv \left\langle A \right\rangle \) of a number of measurements of \(A\) is $$ \bar{A} \equiv \left\langle A \right\rangle = \frac{\left\langle u|A| u \right\rangle}{\left\langle u|u \right\rangle} $$
With \( u \) an eigenstate of \( \Rightarrow \left| u \right\rangle = \left| \phi_{i} \right\rangle \), \( A \left| \phi_{i} \right\rangle = \lambda_{i} \left|\phi_{i} \right\rangle \) $$ \bar{A} = \frac{\left\langle \phi_{i}|A| \phi_{i} \right\rangle}{\left\langle \phi_{i}|\phi_{i} \right\rangle} = \lambda_{i} \Rightarrow \triangle^{2} = \left\langle A^{2} \right\rangle - \left\langle A \right\rangle ^{2} $$
With \( u \) not an eigenstate of A $$ \left| u \right\rangle = \sum_{i} \left| \phi_{i} \right\rangle \left\langle \phi_{i} \right| \left| u \right\rangle $$
\(u\) in basic of \( \phi_{i} \)
$$ \bar{A} = \sum_{i, j} \frac{\langle u | \phi_{i} \rangle \langle \phi_{i} | A | \phi_{j} \rangle \langle \phi_{j} | u \rangle}{\langle u | u \rangle} = \frac{\sum_{i} \lambda_{i}|\langle u | \phi_{i}\rangle |^{2}}{\sum_{i} | \langle u | \phi_{i} \rangle |^{2}}$$
$$ \bar{A} = \frac{\sum_{i} P_{i} \lambda_{i}}{\sum_{i} P_{i}} $$
Rule 7: A measurement of observable \( A \) resulting in eigenvalue \( \lambda_{i} \) projects the state vector from \( |u\rangle \) to that subspace of the Hilbert space associated with \( \lambda_{i} \). If the eigenvalue is nondegenerate, the subspace is just a single eiggenstate \( \phi_{i} \) associated with \( \lambda_{i} \). If \( |u\rangle \) is already an eigenstate of \( A \), it’s not changed by the measreument. If \( u \) is not an eigenstate of \( A \), then in the nondegenerate case it ‘collapses’ to \( \phi_{i} \) with probability \( |\langle u | \phi_{i} \rangle |^{2} \) Rule2 and Rule 7 macroscopic objectification problem
If \( [A, B] = 0 \), then \(A\) and \(B\) are simultaneously diagonalized by the same unitary transformation
If A, B, C, … form a complete set of commuting (compatible) observables then we know everythig there is to know about the steate of the system when we specify the eigenvalue of each of A, B, C, … for that state
This is called a complete set of quantum numbers for that state
$$ \frac{d\langle A \rangle}{dt} = \left(\frac{ d \langle u |}{dt}\right) A |u\rangle + \langle u | A \left(\frac{d |u \rangle}{dt}\right) + \langle u | \left(\frac{\delta A}{\delta t}\right) | u \rangle $$
Employing \( H|u\rangle = i\hbar \delta_{t} |u\rangle \) and \( \langle u | H = -i \hbar \delta_{t} \langle u | \)
$$ \frac{d\langle A \rangle}{dt} = \frac{i}{\hbar} \left[ \langle u | HA | u \rangle - \langle u | AH | u \rangle \right] + \left\langle u \left| \frac{\delta A}{\delta t} \right| u \right\rangle $$
$$ = \frac{i}{\hbar} \langle u | [A, H] | u \rangle + \left\langle u \left| \frac{\delta A}{\delta t} \right| u \right\rangle $$
Carry out unitary transformation into a new basic in which \( u \) is a constant.
$$ S(t, t_{0}) = U^{\dagger}(t, t_{0}) = e^{\left[ -\frac{i}{\hbar}\int_{t_{0}}^{t} H(t^{\prime}) dt^{\prime} \right]^{\dagger}} $$
Giving us the Heisenberg equation for uncertainty
$$ A^{\prime} = SAS^{\dagger} = U^{\dagger}AU \Rightarrow \frac{dA^{\prime}}{dt} = \frac{1}{i\hbar} [A^{\prime}, H] + \frac{\delta A^{\prime}}{\delta t}$$

Quantum computation and quantum information.   Cambridge University Press.

Ising model is an approximation model that captures the evolution of states influenced by their neighbor states and an external agent. It was first introduced to tackle the problem of phase transition of ferromagnetism but later adopted into other fields of science. In this review of Ising model, we will explore three solutions to the one dimensional Ising model and how each methods give insight to the model itself and its relation with other branches of mathematics.
Statistical Mechanics: Existence of Equilibrium (ergodicity) Computer Science: NP versus P problem (maximum cut problem) Dynamical System: Existence of stable orbit and fixed point () Statistical Mechanics: Universality Introduction Before getting into the mathematical description of the Ising model, we first answer the question of how it is applicable in physical situaition such as the case of ferromagnetic material.
In the quantum mechanic perspective of interacting atom, we need to take into the coupling of the orbital and spin angular momentum into account to derive the Hamiltonian in the system.
In the case of ferromagnetic materials, it turn out that from theoretical and experimental investigations have so far shown that, for all ferromagnetic materials, data on the temperatuer depenednece of M fit best with the values of \( J = 1/2 \) and \( g = 2.0023\approx 2 \) in this model. So, we could only consider the spin degree of freedom. It is also reasonable that the spin interaction is short range, meaning only the neighboring atoms matters to the evolution of the states of a chosen atom.
Writing out the Hamiltonian for arbitrary dimension we get
$$ H = -2J \sum_{i>j}\sigma_{i} \sigma_{j} - \mu B \sum_{i} \sigma_{i} $$
Renormalization Group Method The general procedure of renormaliation group method is recursively carrying out decimation and rescaling such that the essential properties of the system remain unchanged. This procedure underlies one of the essential properties of thermodynamics, scale invariance. Imaging we scaled down the number of atoms in a Ising model to half as much, we would expect that the thermodynamics properties would remain unchanged.
One could also treat the recursive step of RG method as flow and draw connection with the study of dynamical system. Different from the flow lines in dynamical system which describes the trajectory as time varies, the RG flow describes the flow as the size of the system shrinks. From this description we could quantitaively measures the scale invariance as the correlation length of the system. The fixed point in the flow lines is where the continuous phase transition takes place. The fixed point happens when the correlation length becomes zero of infinite.
In the case of one dimension Ising model, every resursive process scales the total number of lattice by \( \frac{1}{2} \) while keeping the form of partition function fixed. As a result, the coupling constant \( g \equiv \frac{J}{T} \) is mapped to \( g^{\prime} \) accordingly to match the partition function.
By scaling the lattice point by half, the transfer matrix is rescaled as such
$$ T^{\prime}=e^{f^{\prime}}[[e^{g^{\prime}+h^{\prime}}, e^{-g^{\prime}}], [e^{-g^{\prime}}, E^{g^{\prime} - h^{\prime}}]] = e^{2f}[e^{2g+2h} + e^{-2g}] $$
Which gives us three equations to solve for the three new coupling constant in terms of the old coupling constant. Writting out explicitly.
The renormalized external magnetic field $$ h^{\prime} = h + \frac{1}{2}\ln{\left[ \frac{\cosh{(2g+h)}}{\cosh{2g-h}} \right]} $$ In the absent of external magnetic field
The renormalized free energy $$ f^{\prime} = 2f + + \ln{\left( 2 \sqrt{2\cosh{2g}} \right)} $$
The renormalized nearest-neighbor interaction $$ \tanh{g^{\prime}} = \tanh^{2}g $$
The RG flow and fixed points Defining \( x_{0} \) to be
$$ x_{0} = \tanh{\left( \frac{J}{T} \right)} = \tanh{g} $$
which follows that
$$ \tanh{g_{1}} = x_{1} = x_{0}^{2} $$
And we obtain the recursion relation of the fraction \( g \)
$$ x_{n+1} = x_{n}^{2} $$ $$ x_{n} = \tanh{\left( \frac{J}{T_{n}} \right)} $$
Since hyperbolic tangent is asmptotic to -1 and +1, hence the recursion will map the hyperbolic tangent from \( |1| \) to \( 0 \), or zero temperature to infinite temperature as we shrinks the system.
Alternatively, the RG flow could be captured by calculating the correlation function \( G(r_{i} - r_{j}) \) and the correlation length \( \xi \). Recall that \( \xi \) is defined in terms of the asymptotic behavor of the correlation function \( G(r_{i} - r_{j}) \) for \( |r_{i} - r_{j}| \rightarrow \infty \), or, equivalently, in terms of the behavior of its Fourier transfrom \( G(k) \) for small wave vectors.
$$ \xi^{\prime} \equiv \xi (x^{\prime}) = \frac{\xi (x)}{b} $$
$$ \xi (x^{2}) = \frac{\xi (x)}{2} $$
$$ \xi (x) = - \frac{a_{0}}{\ln{x}} $$
Hence
$$ \xi \sim \frac{a}{2} e^{2J/T} $$

Hidden Subgroup Problem Lef \( f \) be a function from a finitely generated group \( G \) to a finite set \( X \) such that \( f \) is constant on the cosets of a subgroup \( K \), and distinct on each coset. Given a quantum black box for performing the unitary transform \( U \left| g \right\rangle \left| h \right\rangle = \left| g \right\rangle \left| h \oplus f(g) \right\rangle \), for \( g \in G \), \( h \in X \), and \( \oplus \) an appropriately chosen binary operation on \( X \), find a generating set for \( K \).
Fortunately, it does turn out to be possible to utilize the quantum FOurier Transform to efficiently solve server problems that are believed to have no efficient solution on a classical computer. These problems include Deutsch’s problem, and Shor’s algorithms for discrete logarithm and factoring. This line of though culminated in Kitaev’s discovery of a method to solve the Abelian Stabilizer problem, and the gernationlizationto the hidden subgroup problem
The Deutsch-Jozsa algorithm, Shor’s algorithms, and related ’exponentially fast’ quantum algorithms can all be viewd as special cases of this algorithm.
